text: WE OPEN on a montage of varied ETHNIC COMMUNITIES from th different boroughs of NEW YORK CITY. CARS, PEDESTRIANS an CITY SOUNDS intersect and blend with the beat of the musi
A door opens and a pair of BEAT UP CONVERSE KICKS step outside. They belong to NATASHA KINGSLEY, 17, beautiful, an enormous afro. The sun on her face makes her smile.

I don’t care what anyone says... New York’s the best city in the world. While on her phone, Natasha struts by local shops: a Pakistani restaurant with a line of CAB DRIVERS out the d an Optimo cigar store, and a Taiwanese electronics store.
It's a place where 8.5 million people coexist--
Passengers rush down the stairs as she climbs up to the “ train station at 167th. Thick Jamaican accents blend with Spanish and Haitian French. Natasha listens, smiles.
It’s a lot to take in. A train whizzes by revealing her on the platform.
Natasha emerges from the “A” train at 175th. BEVERLY “BEV RAMIREZ, 17, Dominican, waits anxiously. They’re late. Th girls rush off arm-in-arm.
But with a little luck you can find a best friend.
A number of SENIORS stand in line. “Congratulations Class 2019 - The Bronx High School of Science” is on the marque Natasha and Bev squeeze in as the line moves forward.
It's a city where hard work and determination are constants against unknown variables in the equation for success--
Inside the ornate auditorium, velvet seats are filled wit FAMILY and FRIENDS. The STUDENTS, now dressed in graduati caps and gowns, enter single file to Pomp and Circumstanc
PRINCIPAL and FACULTY on stage. Natasha’s poised at the e Like a runner in blocks. Her name is barely called when s Marches across the stage to claim her diploma.
...And dreams can become tangible when you reach out and grab them.

A Caribbean-American Graduation Party in full swing. Ligh strung from corner posts. A Jamaican flag stretched acros the fence. Jerk chicken and fish on the grill. Dishes wit curried goat, oxtails, plantains, peas and rice. ADULTS i traditional garb. And TEENS on a makeshift dance floor. F Natasha and Bev in the middle. Dancing. Laughing.

I wouldn’t have wanted this perfect night to happen anywhere but here: the city I’m proud to call my home. On Tasha’s face, smiling as she looks at the night sky fi with fireworks and stars. Twinkling. It’s truly magical.
INT. NATASHA’S APARTMENT - DAY - REALITY A NASA STAR MAP on a wall. Pull out to reveal Tasha in a small apartment, moving boxes everywhere.
Or at least a city I used to call my home.
Behind her, a LITTLE HAND pulls back the bright blue curt separating the room. REVEAL: PETER, 9 years old, chocolat with dreadlocks and a grin from ear to ear.
Unless a cataclysmic blunder is corrected, the odds of me actually graduating with my friends are declining. Rapidly. Peter whips the curtain closed, unseen.

You see, I’m an illegal immigrant and my family is scheduled for deportation. Tomorrow. WHOOSH - Natasha pulls back the curtain. Peter is jugglin soccer ball on his knees in the next room. ZOOM in on Pet
Look, Tasha! Peter fumbles with the ball. The ball gets away from him, bumping into a neat stack of Natasha’s books.
How many times do I have to tell you not to practice in our room?! Peter picks his nose and examines what he dug up. NATASHA (CONT’D) Ewww! Peter, stop it. You’1l never get friends that way.

Doesn't matter. I’1l make new friends in Jamaica! Natasha sighs heavily, the weight of her family’s struggl on her shoulders. A key RATTLES in the lock. MRS. KINGSLEY, Natasha’s 40-ish, world-weary mother, drag from work wearing a waitress uniform.  4. She sees a kitchen full of dirty dishes. NOTE: Mr. And Mr Kingsley both speak with a heavy Jamaican accent and dial
Tasha. How many times I’m gonna have to tell you to clean the dishes before I come home?
You haven’t even closed the door yet and you're already yelling--
It's not enough to pick up dirty plates at work? I come home to pick up dirty plates too?!

Mom, please. I’11 do it now. Mrs. Kingsley heads to her bedroom. Natasha goes into the kitchen, draws soapy water and washes the dishes. Mrs. Kingsley emerges from the bedroom wearing a bathrobe. NATASHA (CONT’D) You work too much.

Somebody gotta keep a roof over all our heads, child. Who else gonna do it? REVEAL: MR. KINGSLEY, late 40s, small frame, sad eyes, sitting in front of the TV. We haven’t noticed him until Mr. Kingsley watches as LAWRENCE OLIVIER performs a monol from “Othello” on screen. He studies him intently.

My father’s an actor. At least, that’s why he came to America. But that’s not exactly how it’s worked out. PULL OUT: Mr. Kingsley performs the scene along with Oliv He’s in perfect sync with the actor on TV.
It’s his fault we’re in this mess. Natasha finishes the dishes. Mrs. Kingsley makes eggs.
You want breakfast?
I have an appointment at the Immigration Office this morning. It's at eight.
You don’t think it’s time for you to give up now, Tasha? You don’t think what you’re doing is futile? Natasha grabs a piece of fruit off the table.
There’s still time, Mommy. We have today. And I’m going to use every last second. Can’t give up yet.
Don’t think of it as giving up. Think of it as embracing destiny.
I’d rather make my own. Peter smiles, turns up Sister Nancy’s “Bam Bam” and sings along. Natasha rolls her eyes. She grabs her headphones a her Physics textbook.
(re: textbook) We leaving, Tasha. You don’t have to turn in homework. We’re free!
I’ll be back later.
You have a lot to finish here. I still see open boxes in your room.
Mom, I really gotta go. Natasha heads for the door, determined. She takes a deep breath, opens the door and steps outside.
Natasha stops at a specific spot on the platform and chec her phone: 6:55 AM. She looks down the track-- nothing.

Ugh. Come on. Not today.  INT. DANIEL’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - DAY DANIEL JAE HO BAE, 17, stands in front of a mirror sizing himself up in the suit he’s wearing. He adjusts his red t clearly uncomfortable in what he’s wearing.
Today's the day my whole life has led up to... From outside the room, his mother, MIN SOO, 40s, calls ou
(in Korean) Daniel! I’m making you a special breakfast. Hurry down.
The day of my college interview for Yale.
Coming!
The day that decides my future. Behind him, shelves full of the world’s greatest poets: Shakespeare, Shelly, Frost, Poe, Plath, Angelou, Hughes.

Normally I’d write a two-page poem about something of this magnitude. At least a haiku. But today, my anxiety’s holding me hostage. Daniel grabs his writer’s notebook, throws it into his satchel. Takes one final glance at himself.
Because I need every brain cell focused on nailing this interview. Daniel takes one final glance at himself, then exits.
Daniel’s mother steams frozen dumplings. Daniel pours a b of Cap’n Crunch. She shakes her head disapprovingly. Min speaks with a heavy Korean accent.
Too much sugar. You need a sharp mind today. She grabs the bowl of cereal, replaces it with a plate of dumplings, and pours the dry cereal back into the box.
I’m pretty sure I inherited my mother’s anxiety...
YOUNG MIN SOO and YOUNG DAE HYN, nervous and afraid, pres their paperwork to the CUSTOMS AGENT.

Which started the day she uprooted her whole life in Korea to come to America. For most immigrants, moving to a foreign country is an act of faith. What if you can’t adapt? What if you’re not welcomed? What if you lose all sense of your identity and culture?

FAMILY and FRIENDS crowd the apartment. Min Soo holds her first born, CHARLIE, as ONE-YEAR-OLD DANIEL crawls toward various objects: a stethoscope, pen, basketball, etc. Eac object represents a career or “fate.” THIS IS A KOREAN DOLJANCHI or “DOL” where the child “chooses their destiny

So when my brother and I were born, she gave us both an American name and a Korean name. So we would know where we were from. And where we were going. The family cheers as Young Daniel nears the stethoscope, grabs the PEN instead to his parents’ dismay.
Min Soo interrogates her son between his bites of breakfa
How’s your grade in math? You don’t like math.
B plus. But the rest are A’s.

Why no A in math yet, Daniel? Aigo! It's time you get serious... (then, in Korean) Don’t be like your brother. Right as she says this, Daniel’s brother, CHARLIE, 19, wa into the kitchen. Pretends he doesn’t hear this, but his resentful demeanor gives him away.
I made mandu.
Awww. Daniel’s “special breakfast.” I‘ll pass. Charlie strokes Daniel’s hair. Daniel slaps his hand away
My brother, Charlie, is an asshole. Charlie grabs the box of Cap’n Crunch, then pours cereal milk into a bowl and sits. He chomps loudly with each bit
He’s been at home the past semester because he failed too many classes at BU. An epic screw up that my parents can’t accept.
Close your mouth when you eat. Charlie ignores her then SLURPS the remaining milk from t bowl. He stands, looks down at Daniel.

Good luck with your day, little brother. Charlie tries to touch Daniel’s hair again and is batted away. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Wouldn’t want to disappoint Mommy and Daddy if you don’t get into an Ivy. Charlie exits, leaving his dirty bowl on the table.
I should hate Charlie, but these days, I mostly feel sorry for him.
I just don’t understand what happened to your brother. Why he can’t behave, like you.
Umma, give him a break. Daniel finishes the last of the dumplings. Grabs his plat and hand washes it in the sink. Min Soo looks over her son, eyes honing in on his bun.
You cut your hair before the interview. Daniel groans, but Min Soo is not having it.
Too long. You look like a girl.
They let girls into Yale, too. Min Soo scolds him with her eyes, then hands him a money pouch with deposit slips.
Appa forgot this. You bring it to him. After you get a hair cut. Daniel takes the pouch. Kisses his Mom on the cheek.
Alright, Umma. I’1l get it cut. (off her skeptical look) I promise. Daniel grabs his bag and heads for the door.
Daniel makes his way through his busy Queens neighborhood passing a slew of restaurants, bars and vendors, etc., al written in Korean.  10.
Natasha frantically charges through the MULTI-CULTURAL RAINBOW of IMMIGRANTS. Heads over to the RECEPTIONIST. Sweating and short of breath.
Natasha Kingsley for Karen Whitney. The Receptionist checks her appointment sheet, and shakes head.
You’re too late. You’1l have to call the main USCIS line and make a new appointment.
No, you don’t understand. I can’t reschedule!
I’m sorry. You’ll have to call the main line. The Receptionist shrugs and looks down, dismissing Natash Natasha starts to panic.
I don’t have time for that. This is an emergency. The trains were delayed. (getting emotional) Just-- could you please call Ms. Whitney? She told me to come back.
Your appointment was for 8 AM. It is now 8:15. She’s seeing another--
Please. Just call her. Now! Natasha’s now hysterical voice rings through the receptio area. The other applicants stare in her direction.

I guess ‘desperation’ translates into every language. The Receptionist nods at a SECURITY GUARD standing by the door. He sets his jaw and turns toward Natasha.  11. But before he can reach her, another door opens. A tall, thin, brown-skinned man beckons Natasha: LESTER BARNES, 4

(to the Receptionist) It's alright, Mary. I’1ll take her. INT. USCIS - LESTER BARNES’S OFFICE - MINUTES LATER Natasha sits in front of an immaculately kept desk. Turns Lester enters with a RED FILE in his hand.
My name is Lester Barnes.
Hi, I’'m-- He holds up a hand to silence her.

Everything I need to know is in this file. Do yourself a favor and stay quiet while I read it. Natasha falls silent. Reaches across his desk and pockets of his business cards. After a beat, Lester finally looks LESTER (CONT’D) Why are you here?
Karen--Ms. Whitney--told me to come back. She said maybe there was something--

Yeah, well Karen’s new. Your family’s last appeal was rejected. The deportation stands as is. You and your family will have to leave tomorrow. He closes the file and pushes a box of tissues toward her anticipation of her tears. Natasha shakes it off.

I didn't cry when my father told us about the deportation orders. I’m not going to start crying now. Natasha gathers her things. Heads for the door. But she s with her hand on the knob, swallows her pride. Turns arou  12.
So there’s really nothing you can do to help me? He taps the closed file with his fingers.
Your dad’s DUI--
Is his problem. Why do I have to pay for his mistake?

You’re still here illegally. Natasha nods, on the verge of tears. She heads for the do LESTER (CONT’D) I’ve been to your country. I’ve been to Jamaica. He smiles at the memory as Natasha turns back to him. LESTER (CONT’D) I had a nice time. Everything is irie there, man. You'll be alright. Natasha glares at Lester.
Where did you go?
Negril. Very nice place.
Did you leave the hotel grounds?
I wanted to but my--
But your wife didn’t want to because was she scared, right?
No, it’s just--  13.

You listened to Bob Marley, and a bartender got you some pot and someone told you what irie means, and now you think you know something. That is not a country. That is a resort. He holds up his hands, defending himself. NATASHA (CONT’D) Don’t tell me I'll be alright. I don’t know that place. I’ve been here since I was eight years old. Now it’s my senior year. I should be worrying about the same things my friends are-- like prom and graduation. But instead I’m worrying about being shipped to a country that’s totally foreign to me. This is my home! Natasha’s tears finally pour out. Mr. Barnes slides the tissue box closer. She takes a handful, then heads to the door--
Wait.
Daniel leans against a street light, checking his phone. JUMPS as someone WHISTLES loudly in his ear. He turns--
What the--? Reveal OMAR HASSABALA, 19, Middle Eastern, raised on Hip
I thought you were going to wait until right before the meeting to put the stick up your ass.
Don’t be mad because I’m going to be part of the one percent. Omar checks out Daniel’s suit, laughing.
You look like a Lebanese insurance salesman.  14.
You’re supposed to be making me feel better about going to Yale.
That's what I’m doing. Easing your impending sense of doom with the use of comedy. It’s a known tactic.
Well, try something else.
You could just be like me and not go. How about that?
Unlike you, I actually care about what my parents think. And anyway, the interview’s today. Too late to back out now. Omar shrugs and leads the way down the subway stairs.
You’re supposed to wear black to a funeral by the way. Not gray. Daniel playfully hits Omar and they descend into the subw
Tasha stares at a business card and dials the number on i WOMAN answers the line.
Mr. Fitzgerald's office.
Hi, I'd like to make an appointment with Mr. Fitzgerald as soon as possible, please.
Who am I speaking with?
Natasha Kingsley.

Hi, Natasha. What issue can I help you with?  15. Tasha hesitates, afraid to say the words aloud. Silence. WOMAN (V.O., CONT’D) Hello, ma’am? He does have a slot at 11 A.M. Can you tell me your issue?
I’m an illegal alien. Tasha’s heart races, afraid. We see the giant imposing federal buildings surrounding her as she sits on the step
Daniel and Omar sit in the congested subway car. Daniel l at his reflection in the shiny metal subway door. Turns s can see his ponytail.
You should just let me cut your hair. I brought my pocket knife.
No, thanks.
Your mom’s right, you gotta lose the man bun. You don’t want to be a virgin forever.
You know, if this interviewer’s so smart, he’ll recognize a cool haircut when he sees one.
Or at least a desperate attempt at cool. The train COMES TO A SCREECHING HALT. The friends, along the other PASSENGERS, wait patiently for a beat. THEN, a super CHIPPER VOICE over the loudspeaker...
Looks like we got a slight delay, folks. Track work on 68th. A collective GROAN from the passengers.
I know you’re all panicking, thinking that you’re late... (MORE )
but look on the bright side, maybe the universe is telling you something. GROANS again.
I knew we should’ve taken the express.
Happens to me all the time. Something goes off in my routine -- boom...must be the Universe. It’s full of unexpected blessings.
Usually the nut jobs are on the train, not driving it.

Deli screws up my order. Universe... Maybe I shouldn’t be eatin’ deli sandwiches all the time. Guess what? I switched it up and lost twenty pounds. Thank you, universe. The train does a collective eye roll in complete disbelie
This guy needs a drug test. The Conductor goes quiet. After a few more seconds in the dark, the train finally pulls into Grand Central.
We've reached the end of the line. Ladies and gentlemen, back to your regularly scheduled program. Passengers breathe a sigh of relief as the DOORS OPEN.

This train is now out of service. But remember: The universe is talking... So slow down and listen. Omar rises from his seat and heads to the exit. Daniel SI beat, taking in the conductor’s words.  17.
Daniel and Omar emerge from the train to find themselves the main concourse of Grand Central Station.
How much time you got before work?
‘Bout an hour. Why? Daniel looks to the walkways situated behind on the massi windows overlooking the terminal.
It's been a while since we went up. Today’s the perfect day. Daniel starts to make his way through the diverse crowd o people rushing to their trains.
Come on! Omar follows after Daniel, almost losing sight of him in pedestrian traffic. EXT. TASHA’S HIGH SCHOOL - DAY Tasha stands outside the fence of her school. Fighting te

It’s still hard for me to believe that after today I may never see this school again. INSERT SHOTS: She and Bev sitting down at the courtyard outside laughing, walking the hallways, gossiping, etc. BACK TO SCENE: The real Bev walks up.
Please tell me you have good news.
Bev’s the closest thing I have to a sister. The longest time we’ve ever been apart is two weeks.
I wish. I was late, so they wouldn’t let me see Ms. Whitney.  18.
(desperate) So what does that mean? You're leaving?! Isn’t there someone else you can talk to? Tasha pulls out the card.
I’ve got one last shot. This guy Jeremy Fitzgerald. He’s supposed to be some kind of immigration fixer.
Oh my God! That’s amazing! (then) Wait, why are you here? He should be “fixing” this! Go!
I’ve got a few hours before my appointment with him.
You should come to Chem Lab and mess with Mr. Busby. He’s got on his polyester mom jeans again.
My appointment’s uptown. I don’t want to rush. I’m just gonna hit the record store. Kill some time. The bell rings.
Text me the address. I’'1l skip out after my test and we can grab lunch.
Perfect. They share a look. Bev heads back inside. Tasha puts her headphones on and queues up Major Lazer album. We hear GE FREE and see it carry her worries away.
Daniel and Omar chill behind the oversized windows of the main terminal, overlooking the bustling crowd below. All Grand Central’s architectural glory in perfect view.  19.
My life’s gonna go one of two ways after today. If I don’t get into Yale, it’ll be Charlie all over again. And if I do...white jackets and picket fences from now until eternity.
The American Dream.
Even if I win, I lose. What kind of future is that?
If losing means you're rich, sign me up.
I just wish I could do something about it. Daniel sighs. He turns over and lies face up on the walkw
There's gotta be something more to it all than this. His gaze catches the gigantic mural of the Universe paint on the ceiling of the terminal.
You ever notice that before?
Notice what? Off Daniel’s look, Omar joins him on the ground, eyes up. majesty of the mural is on full display. Several constellations are recognizable.
It’s a sign.
Oh, see now, you’re just making stuff up. We’ve passed this thing a million times.  20.
Yeah, but have you ever seen it? It's like the conductor said on the train, maybe the universe is trying to tell me something.
Yep. “You’re losing it, bro.”
I’m serious, Omar. Of all the days we've been here, today is the day that I notice the most amazing thing in all of Grand Central? It’s not a coincidence.

Okay, then let’s suppose this conductor was right...the universe is talking. What’s it saying? Daniel sits up, looking out into the main terminal. Peopl shuffle back through the concourse. He looks around, eyei everything in sight...nothing. A train pulls in.
I don’t know yet.

Go figure. Daniel plops down on the ground, then... He spots HER in crowd. A young, Black woman with an enormous, curly AFRO almost-as-enormous PINK HEADPHONES. It’s Natasha. Her eyes are closed as she sways to her music, in complet bliss. Omar notices Daniel’s gaze and shakes his head.

Now what? (looking out) It’s just a cute girl, Daniel. Relax. (double take) Okay, she’s real cute. Natasha walks underneath them, moving her backpack to one shoulder REVEALING the back of her jacket. It reads: CARP DIEM. Daniel’s completely struck.
Look at her jacket! Carpé Diem.  21.
Carpé wha--
Carpé Diem... “Seize the Day.” (off Omar, unfazed) It's gotta be a sign. C’mon on! Daniel drags Omar off in the direction he last saw Natash
Daniel’s eyes light up as he follows Natasha from a dista
This is stalker-ish, you know.
No, it’s not. I’m maintaining a non- creepy, half-block distance. Tasha enters a record store. GALAXY RECORDS. Daniel stops his tracks. Stares at Omar.
(re: the store’s sign) You gotta be shitting me! This is definitely a Sign.
Okay. Definitely ironic. I'll give you that... And she is cute...
I want to know where this leads.
Hopefully not to jail. But if it does, don’t call me.
Natasha enters the record store, smiling anyway.
If today were not today, I would spend all day here. Tasha enters the “Rap” section. Then she sees a COUPLE ma out next to a poster of Madonna's Like a Virgin. She frow  22.

Ugh. Of all the people to run into, on today of all days, why did I have to run into my ex? Why isn’t he in school? This is my place! These two are ROB, 17, and KELLY, 17. Kelly snakes her ha out and SNATCHES A RECORD. She slips it between their bod and into her bulky jacket. Tasha shakes her head, appalle
She’s just going to steal that? Tasha turns to find Daniel standing right behind her.
I know! Doesn’t anybody work here? Can’t they see what’s happening?
Shouldn't we say something? Tasha shakes her head.
(re: Rob and Kelly) No. I know them.
Sticky Fingers is your friend?
She’s my boyfriend’s girlfriend.
How does that work exactly?
I mean ex-boyfriend. He cheated on me. With her, actually.
TMI, Tasha. I didn’t need to volunteer that tidbit toa stranger.
Great pair. (beat, then) We should tell someone.  23.
No way! If I say something, it’s going to look like I’m jealous and messing with them.
Are you?
That's kind of a personal question, isn’t it?
We were having a moment.

Were we? Rob pauses from making out, looks up to see Tasha and Dan staring at them from a distance. NATASHA (CONT’D) Jesus Christ bleeding on a popsicle stick...he saw me! Rob gives Tasha a half-smile and a small wave. Tasha turn her back to him, facing Daniel instead. NATASHA (CONT’D) Oh God...is he coming over here?
Yup.
Maybe we should make out or something. Like spies do in the movies. Daniel blushes. Hard. Tasha notes his blush and leans back. NATASHA (CONT’D) I’m not serious. Obviously. Rob approaches them.
Hey...
Why are you and your girlfriend stealing things?  24. Rob holds his hands up and takes a step back.
Whoa, dude. Keep your voice down.

This is an independent record store. That means it’s family owned. You’re stealing from real people. Do you know how hard it is for small businesses to survive when people like you just take stuff? Tasha spots an EMPLOYEE approach Kelly.
Uh...don’t look now, but I think your girlfriend just got busted. Rob looks over at Kelly. EMPLOYEE #2 has now joined them. shoves his hands into his pockets and walk-runs toward th front door.
Rob! But Rob doesn’t stop. He bolts out, leaving her behind.
Damn, that was cold. Kelly hands Employee Prince’s “Purple Rain” from under he jacket. The employee snatches the record.
Come back in here again and I will call the cops. Kelly nods, then exits quickly.
Well, at least she has good taste.
Yeah, I guess if you’re going to steal a Prince record, might as well be his best one, right?
I don’t know if that’s his best one. Solid top three, for sure.  25.
Tell me, in your opinion, what is his best album?
Controversy. My mom used to play that song all the time when I was a kid. Tasha smiles, impressed. Daniel stares at her, googly-eye Grinning.
Listen, Red Tie--
Daniel. My name is Daniel. He sticks out his hand for a shake. Tasha shakes it. He h it a beat too long. A moment passes between them.
It was nice meeting you, Daniel. But I really have to go--
Well, maybe I can walk you--
No, I’m good. Take care, Daniel. Tasha puts her headphones back on and starts walking for door quickly, leaving Daniel standing there kicking himse

Natasha walks out into the crowd and spots Rob and Kelly ahead. Kelly cries as Rob gives his best half-ass explanation. Natasha moves past them unnoticed. Daniel, ear to his phone, eyes Tasha in the distance as h follows her.
Why didn’t you just get her number in the record store?
Because she wouldn’t give it to me.
I think that’s clearly a sign, don’t you?  26.
But it’s not like she totally blew me off. She was nice. I’m telling you, there was a spark there.
And following her like a serial killer is going to reignite that?
I’m not following her. She just happens to be going my way. Natasha stops at the crosswalk ahead of Daniel.
Oh, shit, I’m getting close. She'd definitely think I was stalking her if she turned around now.

Well, then whatever you do, don’t -- Daniel hangs up in a panic. Strains, deciding whether to or say something as he approaches. Daniel takes a deep breath. He’s about to veer off when-- A WHITE BMW flies down the avenue. The light turns red ag and Natasha STEPS OFF THE CURB, not paying attention. SHE’S ABOUT TO GET HIT when Daniel YANKS her backwards by arm. They fall backwards onto the sidewalk. Natasha lands half on top of Daniel as her phone and headphones CRASH AGAINST THE PAVEMENT. She looks down at spider webs cracking across her phone’s screen.
What. The. Hell?
You okay?

That guy almost killed me. She looks up the block as the BMW sits on the side of the road with its blinkers on. Then looks to her headphones. NATASHA (CONT’D) Do you know how long I’ve had these? Natasha cradles her broken headphones in her hands.  27.
I‘1l buy you another pair. She shakes her head “no.”
It’s the least I can do. Tasha finally looks at him.
You already saved my life.
You wouldn't have died. A little maimed, maybe. Natasha stares back at him, unfazed. Her eyes fill with tears.
I’m having just the worst day. (a beat; realizing) Wait. Were you following me?
Man, I knew you would think that.
You just happened to be right behind me?
Maybe it was meant to be. Natasha exhales deep.
I’m just gonna ignore that. Thanks for your help.
At least tell me your name.
Natasha.
Nice name.
So glad you approve. Daniel stares at her, inquisitive.  28. NATASHA (CONT’D) Why are you staring at me? Daniel blushes again. Natasha stares at his face. His hai
Observable Fact: The man-bun pushes him from cute to kind of sexy.
Now you're staring. Tasha blushes, then clears her throat.
Why are you wearing a suit?
I have an interview later. Wanna go get something to eat?
What for?
Yale. Alumni admission interview. I applied Early Decision. Natasha shakes her head.
No, I meant why do you want to get something to eat?
I’m hungry?
Hmmm. I’m not.
Coffee then? Or tea or soda or bottled water?
Why? Daniel shrugs.
Why not? Besides, I’m pretty sure you owe me your life since I just saved it.
Daniel and Tasha sit across from each other at a Tasha checks the time on her phone: 10:00 A.M.
Wait. Why aren’t you in school?

(lying) . ; I have a doctor’s appointment in an hour. Tasha sips her coffee. Silence. 29. cozy table. Daniel fidgets nervously. Blows on his cappuccino so hard little foam flies up on his face. Tasha chuckles. She then looks at his satchel, suddenly curious. NATASHA (CONT’D) What do you keep in there?
Not much. My notebook. I carry it pretty much everywhere I go. Daniel pulls out a black notebook. Flips through Tasha glances at it. Sees the handwritten blocks
You're not a poet, are you?
No, I just kind of dabble in it. For fun. Next year I‘ll be pre-med. Self-conscious, Daniel quickly puts the notebook bag. Tasha notices, leans in.
(flirting) So what are your poems about? Love?
Among other things. Yes, love.
I don’t believe in love.
Well it exists, whether you believe in it or not. it quickly. of text. back in his  He laughs. 30.
Oh really? Can you prove it?
Thousands of love songs. Poetry. The institution of marriage.
Words on paper. Never mind the fact that eating large amounts of chocolate has the same effect on you as falling in love.
I love chocolate. Tasha laughs, too.
You say it’s just words on paper, but you have to admit all those people are feeling something.
